p: As of April 2015, at least 72 CRFs have been identified globally ( http://www.hiv.lanl.gov/). Although HIV-1 subtypes A, B and C remained the most prevalent genotypes worldwide, CRFs can be attributed to at least 16% of HIV-1 infections globally and are anticipated to increase in proportion [ 2]. Similar patterns can be observed in Asia, where the complexity and diversity of HIV-1 increases in parallel to the cumulated number of HIV-1 infections, though the rates and extent varies [ 3, 4].
